Triggering Event: The school was quiet as she walked through the empty halls, the echoes of children's laughter still lingering in the stale air. She stopped by the classroom door, her eyes scanning the rows of desks now vacant and cold. A single red apple lay untouched on one desk, its owner having forgotten it in their rush to leave at the end of the day. She picked it up, feeling its smooth skin against her fingers, a reminder of the countless apples she had packed for her own son's school lunches years ago. The weight of the fruit was heavy in her hand as she realized once again that no one would be there to greet her when she returned home from this empty building. She sighed, placing the apple back down gently before continuing on her way alone.

Triggering Event: At 3 AM, Dr. H. was jarred awake by his phone ringing. It was the hospital. A young patient's vitals had suddenly plummeted; they were rushing him into emergency surgery. As he rushed to dress, his mind raced with worst-case scenarios. By the time he reached the hospital, his heart pounding in his chest, he felt like he couldn't breathe.

Because I don't have anything better to do than drop everything in the middle of the night for some random person who doesn't even know me! What if the patient is... *dramatic pause*...dead? Would anyone really blame me if I just stayed in bed and ignored the call? I mean, why bother when life is so precious? I guess I'll just stay up all night worrying about this guy until I can't take it anymore. Maybe then I'll get to sleep. Triggering Event: At 64, he still woke early out of habit. Today was different; he'd promised his late wife's favorite students he'd lead their reunion breakfast. He prepared eggs and bacon, but the once-familiar kitchen felt empty without her humming. As he set the table for eight, he noticed a seat empty - she would've been there. Disappointment settled in as he realized no amount of preparation could fill that void.
Generated Assessment: Ugh! I can't believe it. I'm so upset. The worst part is, I don't even know why I am. It just feels like I missed something important. I remember everything about this morning perfectly, down to the last detail. But somehow, none of it really matters now. That's what hurts me the most. It all started when my husband got up early to make us some breakfast. Normally, we'd have our usual routine going. But today, he seemed distracted. He went through the motions, making eggs and bacon, but it wasn’t the same. When I saw him setting the table, I expected to feel excited. Instead, I felt...empty. Like I was missing something essential, but I couldn’t quite put my finger on it. He had planned a surprise for our friends’ reunion, and I knew how much it meant to them. So, I should be happy, right? But nothing felt right. Even though I remembered every little thing he did—how he cracked each egg with precision, how carefully he cooked the bacon—it didn’t bring back the memories I wanted. I kept thinking about what I’d done wrong, if I could’ve made things better. Now, as I look at the empty chair where my late wife usually sat, I’m overwhelmed by sadness. She’s always been the one who brought people together. Without her, it doesn’t feel complete. Every detail—the way the sunlight streamed through the window, the smell

Triggering Event: While walking home from the lab one evening, he noticed a black van idling nearby, its engine humming softly in the otherwise silent street. The windows were tinted, obscuring the occupants within. He had seen it before, parked outside his apartment building. His heart began to pound as paranoid thoughts raced through his mind. Was someone following him? Had they discovered his secret project at work? He quickened his pace, eyes darting between the van and the shadows ahead. The van's headlights flickered on, casting long, menacing shadows across the pavement. His breath caught in his throat as it began to roll forward, slowly gaining speed behind him.
Generated Assessment: What is wrong with you? You always overthink everything. Can't just relax and enjoy yourself. This time, stop freaking out about nothing. It's probably just some lost tourists who don't even know where they are. What are you so scared of? Stop jumping to conclusions like a crazy person. That van has been there for days; it's just a harmless delivery vehicle. Why can't you just let go? You're such a worrier. Your brain is constantly running scenarios, making up worst-case situations. Relax, take a deep breath. It's not worth stressing over. Just be calm and move on. Geez, chill out. Seriously, what's going on inside that head of yours? Every little thing sets off your paranoia radar. Nothing good ever comes from overthinking. You need to learn how to unwind instead of getting worked up over every minor detail. I swear, you have more anxiety than anyone I've ever met. When will you finally get it through your thick skull that most of this stuff isn't real? Stop labeling yourself as anxious all the time. You never seem to worry when everything goes smoothly. Now, try to focus on something else and stop overanalyzing every little situation. Come on, snap out of it already! You're driving yourself crazy with these wild thoughts. Take a break from your own head games. For once, just leave your brain alone and enjoy the simple things in life. No wonder you're always so stressed out.

Triggering Event: "Midnight, alone in the stockroom. Door creaks shut behind him. Darkness envelops. Sudden scurrying noise. Heart pounds as he fumbles for light switch."
Generated Assessment: "I know people are always trying to outdo me, but I'm just not that driven. Look at them, they're so much more confident than I am. They don't even think about things like this. I'm basically the only one who's scared, right? But it makes sense - I've been working here for 6 months, while they were already hired by then. That guy from HR is definitely the best. He's got a lot more experience, so he wouldn't be nervous like this. And what's up with my coworkers making fun of me? It's not fair, we all work late shifts, they're just better at dealing with it. I can't help how anxious I get; it's just part of being human. The fact that everyone else gets along so well is just not something I can relate to. Maybe if I was more outgoing like them, I'd feel better too."

Triggering Event: He noticed her ring while she was handing him the grant paperwork - a thin band of gold gleaming against her left hand, where his had once been.
Generated Assessment: He thinks I'm so pathetic because he saw my old wedding ring when he handed me the paperwork to sign. I feel like he's mocking me for still having it, even though I just got over a divorce and there's no reason why I couldn't keep it. Why would he think this? Why does he have to be so insensitive? I know he didn't mean anything by it, but I can't help how I feel.

In the quiet of her home office, she sat at her desk, eyes scanning lines of code for what felt like the hundredth time that day. Her fingers paused over the keyboard as a sudden gust of wind rattled the window behind her, startling her. Her heart pounded in her chest like a kick drum, echoing the storm brewing outside. The familiar anxiety began to rise, clawing at her throat. She took a deep breath, trying to focus on the task at hand, but the thought of being alone in the house during another power outage sent shivers down her spine. She reached for her phone, considering calling her daughter, but hesitated, not wanting to worry her. Instead, she turned on every light in the house, the brightness momentarily comforting before plunging into shadow as lightning flashed outside.

Every creak of the old house made her jump, and the silence was oppressive. Triggering Event: She was walking home from work, keys clenched between her teeth, when she noticed the flashing light on her answering machine. It hadn't blinked in years. Her heart pounded as she unlocked the door, dropping her bag onto the floor. She hit play, listening to the voicemail from her son's school nurse: "Mrs., we think it might be appendicitis."

Triggering Event:
Scenario:

He's been at it for hours, meticulously preparing the night's specials in his immaculate kitchen. The orders start coming in, a steady stream of tickets, but it's manageable. Then, a familiar face appears at the pass—his ex-wife's new boyfriend, a critic for the local paper, smirking as he places his order: "The duck, medium-rare. And don't forget the side of arrogance."

The chef feels the heat rise in him, not from the stove this time, but from within. He glares at the man, then at the ticket, his grip tightening on his knife. The kitchen staff exchange uneasy glances. He takes a deep breath, exhales sharply, and gets to work. But every slice, every turn of the flame, fuels the anger simmering inside him. When the plate is finally ready, he slides it onto the pass with more force than necessary, causing the other chefs to jump back.

As the critic's table leaves, carrying their untouched dessert, the chef snatches up a nearby pan and hurls it across the kitchen. It crashes against the wall, sending pieces flying. The room falls silent for a moment before chaos erupts. But the chef is already storming out, leaving his staff to clean up the mess he's made.
Generated Assessment: "Oh my god, this guy is such an asshole! I'm so mad, he has no idea how much stress he puts me through. Every single time he comes in, he's just looking for ways to shit on me. Like, fuck you, dude! You're always saying I should have done this or that differently, like I can even control what he thinks. I swear, if I had a dollar for every time he told me I was doing something wrong, I'd have enough money to quit this job right now. But here we go again, another time, another complaint. Oh boy, I hope he doesn't see me freaking out. I've got to keep a cool head, stay professional... wait, why am I getting defensive? I know exactly why I'm freaking out. This guy's just trying to make himself look better than everyone else. He wants to act like some kind of culinary expert, like he's above all of us just because he's got a fancy degree and a nice car. Newsflash, buddy: cooking isn't about being some pretentious jerk; it's about providing good food to good people. If you think you're too smart for this place, maybe you should get your own restaurant. You wouldn't last a day, trust me. At least here, I don't have to worry about some fucking food blogger telling me how I fucked up. So yeah, let's fire him. No, seriously, let's do it.
